commentBody: Nice puzzle. I didn‚Äôt get the second ‚Äúspun‚Äù answers until the puzzle showed me, but it was an impressive accomplishment.
Uh, well that was fun! Bravo.
These puzzles frustrate me because the spinning could go so many ways. That being said, I got a lot of them right the first time. The other fill was fun. Thanks!
Fun, breezy (perhaps a smidge too breezy for a Sunday?) puzzle!
Excellent theme. Breezy 18 minute solve, and the first time I've gotten 3 straight Sundays I think. 21 days on the streak!
CLASSic puzzle. Loved it

Ha, wow, my head is spinning!  It wasn‚Äôt until I was all done that I fully realized the spinners were each part of two answers.

Pessimist‚Äôs BIOPIC?  WHY DO I BOTHER.

AUTOPSY of a pessimist: EMPTY SPACES.

SCIONS of a COMIC STRIP?  Calvin. Also Bart.

IMPART a je ne sais quoi to the chocolate mousse?  ZAGAT RATED.

QUINTILLION LITCHIS? Could happen in a crossword puzzle.

BRIEF SUMMARY of a lesser HUMMUS: ‚Äúnot enough lemon‚Äù.
In my world both HouMoS and Lychees, as transliterations, have alternative spellings, neither of which would have fitted the theme, but could present a choice in other circumstances.

When I first opened the puzzle and saw the shaded areas, I let out a groan. The groan turned into an "aha" a minute later. This construction was brilliant and a whole lot of fun to solve. The animation upon completion was a great ending!
Whoo, that was fun! Especially when the wheels started spinning!

At 117A I confidently inserted sIDED for [Gave support]. Then rationalised sBS as being an, unknown to me, American building term. That took some time to crack. 

P.S. loved the animation

Masterful construction!

I was spinning my wheels for a while until I got to the revealer. Discovering the BIO, SCI, PSY, LIT, MUS, and ART classes was a wonderful treat after a fun workout. 

The trickiest one for me was the spelling of  the Chinese fruit. I needed QUINTILLION to get LITCHIS. 

Well done, Kareem.
How is NILE a shade of green?
Thanks for taking us on a spin around the block, Kareem! That was fun and clever.  And shout out to the graphics team. Wow!

Fun puzzle, and a clever gimmick (for those that enjoy gimmicky puzzles).

Luckily I've been doing puzzles long enough to know that ROTH is a kind of IRA, the NCAA does sports, AMES has a college in it, and there's an ESTES park or two (or more?) scattered around the USA.

TIL the term CAMP SHIRT, and the name MAGNA tiles (although I suspect those are probably toys I've seen my nieces playing with for years).

But having been an avid reader for over 60 years, and now married into a Chinese family, I've seen lychee, lychi, lichee and lichi, but I don't think I've never seen it spelled with a "t" before.
I'm not even done yet, but what a cool theme.

It took me a bit to figure out what was going on, but when I did, I was quite impressed. I have a goal of finishing the Sunday puzzle in X minutes. Today, even though I had incomplete fills for a while, I made my goal with 16 seconds to spare. If you're interested, I reviewed this for Diary of a Crossword Fiend: https://crosswordfiend.com/2025/04/05/sunday-april-6-2025/#ny Thanks, Mr. Ayas!
That was super fun and challenging, I got 99, well 85% of it but it all made further sense when the circles rotated! Great fun, thank you!
Great, many layered puzzle. My only nit is that I have never seen Music class abbreviated MUS.
I had ‚Äúeras‚Äù instead of ‚Äúurls‚Äù for 64 across for the longest time - thought eras in the Taylor Swift sense!
An audible "OH!" moment today, when the [Void*] revealed the full extent of the theme. Masterful work.

The puzzle seemed very big to me, possibly because I failed to remember that it is a Sunday kind of puzzle.  The wheels seemed daunting, so I ignored them and just solved as much as I could, almost all of the puzzle; then, still puzzled, came to the column for my Do'h! moment, and all was revealed.

Puzzled moments:    

25A:  I have never heard of a CAMPSHIRT, but from the description it did sound pretty camp.

79A: I don't recall ever having done that, but the crosses said HUCKS, so hucks it was.

Went to 97D, wondering how Langston would fit, that far down in the puzzle, saw it would be TED, even though I have read only a couple of his poems (read a lot of Plath)

I was at a loss at the LITCHI/Lychee collision, but Professor Google cleared it up.

Those visual fireworks woke me from my dream state, and seemed like an extra congrats for filling the grid.

Masterfully done, Kareem Ayas, and the congrats should all be yours.  Thank you.
Damn clever puzzle!

I do admit that when I opened the puzzle I went uh-oh. Then I calmed down and just started solving, and it wasn't so bad. Lots of places to go wrong and I had a few of them. Fish before TUNA TACO. Broom before STONE. Dry before WRY (how the hec-k does LEdD relate to Blue?)
And I'm rewarding myself with chocolate because I did figure out how to course correct. I frequently miss the second step in these kinds of puzzles. 

Well done, Kareem.

Wow!  That was a grreat ending!  I sort of caught on with the lion as in quintillion, but didn‚Äôt realize how genius it was until the end. POW,  I knew camp shirt,  it‚Äôs what my mother called it, I‚Äôm over 70.  I knew litchee, it was how a Chinese restaurant in Honolulu spelt it.  I didn‚Äôt know hucks, kept trying to misspell ‚Äúchucks‚Äù.  I knew Ted only because he was more popular in my high school kids‚Äô time than Sylvia, though Brit friends tell me they learned their works together.  I loved getting such an intricate surprise at the end.   Wish such rewards were given more often!  Won‚Äôt forget this one.
Impressive accomplishment, Kareem Ayas. I think I would have appreciated the two clue construction.
Save me

Thank you, Kareem for your hard work! Super fun and no hair pulling involved, just trusting I'd get there. I print it out and solve in pen, so I didn't get the animation part that others have mentioned but I still "spun" the wheels in my mind. Loved the entire "course correction" concept and the multiple payoffs all along the way.

Nice to see TREACLE show up. I learned the word many years ago. Perhaps some of you learned in from the same source.


Once upon a time there were three little sisters,' the Dormouse began in a great hurry; `and their names were Elsie, Lacie, and Tillie; and they lived at the bottom of a well--'
`What did they live on?' said Alice, who always took a great interest in questions of eating and drinking.

`They lived on treacle,' said the Dormouse, after thinking a minute or two.

`They couldn't have done that, you know,' Alice gently remarked; `they'd have been ill.'

`So they were,' said the Dormouse; `very ill.'

Brilliant construction, relatively easy solve. 
Everyone should be happy, right?
I'm happy to mentally attend spin class, but I draw the line at the stretch that is "NILE" green.

I‚Äôm genuinely seeking help. For many crosswords, I don‚Äôt know when I‚Äôm supposed to know that there are things like rebuses, or using an asterisk to mean ‚Äústar,‚Äù or (like Thursdays) answers bouncing onto another line to be complete, or in this case, rotating circles that fill in the rest of the answer once you figure out the answer going the other way.

These articles give away the answers, so my notion is that you‚Äôre not supposed to reference the article for hints. Is there somewhere else to go to find hints of when these weird extras are included in the puzzle?

Any feedback would be helpful.

Thanks!

I liked it. My only nitpick is that not all the wheels spun in the same direction, which made it tricky to figure out how to enter the letters. But this was probably hard enough to construct without worrying about that.

Great fun! I caught on halfway through, which is to me perfect: soon enough to be fun, late enough that the puzzle doesn‚Äôt become too easy. 

In the end I spent a good while finding it was not sIDED but AIDED, which meant hard-core was about muscles rather than  some unknown X-rated acronym.

Too, too cute but I loved it!

Kudos to Kareem Ayas for a brilliant first puzzle. This was a delight  with a wonderful array of food, culture, ethos, and genres.  It went quickly until  91 down.

Didn‚Äôt  mope, learned to cope.
Hoping for more, Mr. Ayas.  Encore!

Wow. https://youtu.be/T0bU9llGUic?si=k69mXCQ371pqeRKr And so, I give myself a "C" and Mr. Ayas an "A+++!!" Had to think my way to QUINTILLION: 

(Bi)llion = 9 = (2*3 + 3) zeros
(Tri)llion = 12 = (3*3 + 3) zeros
(Quad)rillion = 15 = (4*3 + 3) zeros
(QUINT)illion = 18 = (5*3 + 3) zeros.

Not clear to you? Take a spin at a MAT class. Maybe after a nice GAPYEAR.

This is not related to today's puzzle,which I loved, but I'm so excited, so if you'll indulge me. I started doing puzzles with my dad when I was about 8, those crummy puzzles from the NY Daily News. This was mid-20th century. One particular clue that appeared frequently was Ship-Shaped Clock, 3 letters, and it became crosswordese.  I never saw it again in all these decades after I gave up the Daily News, but never forgot the answer. However, when I tried to search for it, I always came up empty. I began to think I had developed memory problems. But I just tried one last time, and bingo, it was the first hit! The answer is NEF. Has anyone ever heard of it?

Struggled with the fill, though---ZAGAT, whatever that IRA was this time, CAMP SHIRTS, and a lot of stuff I had to think at sideways for a while. So my slowest Sunday in a while, though still enjoyable.

[And thanks in advance for the almost inevitable M-W url, which will be posted in defence/explanation of the link between clue and solution. I can actually see there's a connection, I just think it's a tenuous one which ignores a large difference.]

[And also, thanks, I don't need to be told that crossword clues are hints, not definitions. I've got that one covered, too.]

Anything else...? I don't think so, for now.

This absolutely beautiful puzzle almost kicked my ___. And it wasn't the trick--I got that. I was stuck at the cross of 89D and 101A. Although R seemed the most likely for the name of a kid in a fantasy series, it didn't give me the happy music. But if it wasn't an R, then I was in personal natick territory, because beyond R, all letters seemed equally unlikely.

Before resorting to a search on ERHU to see if it was a thing, I flyspecked the grid. Finally noticed that although it is true that if you sIDED with someone, you would be giving them support, sBS as part of a core--human or computer--did not ring bells any more now than it did when I first entered it. 

So I ran the alphabet. Well, technically speaking, because the first letter gave me the happy music. And at that moment I learned that ERHU is, in fact, a thing. 

Can someone bring me another cup of coffee?

As it happens, my kitchen is painted in NILE green, so that helped. The color was picked to coordinate with a landscape of the Maine woods, painted by my grandfather, which hangs by the breakfast table.

As for the rest of the puzzle, I avoided the gimmick squares for as long as possible, and then I got to ZAGA. There was no way I was going to leave that alone, so I figured it out. Very clever! And so was URLS in one's browser "history" and not ERAS.

HUMMUS is one of my favorite foods, too. I'm surprised it's never been in the crossword until now. You can find it in any grocery store--but why would you buy it when it's so easy to make?

1 can chickpeas, drained (save some water)
juice of 1 lemon
1/3 cup tahini
1/4 cup olive oil
4 to five cloves of garlic
3/4 tsp. paprika
3/4 tsp. cumin
cayenne to taste
salt to taste

1. Put them all in a food processor and blend until it's the desired consistency. Add some of the chickpea water to thin it out if needed.

2. Eat it all.

While I was working the Downs I happened to notice the 83A clue and a possible answer came to mind, but I didn't feel like moving the cursor then. Finally, 83A and 51D were the only things left, but I couldn't remember what I had thought of for 83A. I thought of something as I was crawling into bed, but found out this morning that it was wrong. The crossing with 51D was no help; somehow I had made it through 89 years without ever learning the word ZAGAT. So I started an alphabet run on the space right after IMP. That very short run was enough to give 83A away, and I AutoCheck'd through the puzzle in a mere 1:05:19 at the keyboard!

For each course correction there is normal clue and a clue with an asterisk.  Take the 3 shaded letters in the same order as they appear in the answer to the non-asterisk clue.

For example, 5D is the the non-asterisk clue that had the answer BIOPIC.  The shaded letters, in order, are BIO.  Reverse the order to OIB and then apply them in that order to the 3 letter gap to form WHYD OIB OTHER.

This rule works consistently for all the asterick clued answers.

As I‚Äôm sure you know (I‚Äôm saying this for the general audience now), N and √ë are separate letters in Spanish, ene and e√±e, whereas A and √Å are the same letter, with the latter having a stress marker on it. In English, we call these markers ‚Äúaccent marks,‚Äù and we call the √ë an ‚ÄúN with a tilde on it‚Äù because Anglophones don‚Äôt consider the N and √ë two different letters. 

You are right that Spanish speakers don‚Äôt need to refer to the ~ by name very often, but, like the dot on the I and j, it does have a name. 

English speakers have mutated the meaning of ‚Äútilde‚Äù from ‚Äúdiacritical mark‚Äù to ‚Äúdiacritical mark placed above an N‚Äù.

The history of disk vs disk is an interesting one‚Ä¶depending on which company becomes the main one selling the product‚Ä¶The BBC would use one spelling and the US would use another‚Ä¶But that would flip when things like compact discs would arrive and the manufacturer chose the spelling they wanted.  Two identical words‚Ä¶effectively meaning the same thing‚Ä¶But depending on the decade is spelled differently.
